bio.name: Carolyn Napier
bio.why: I became a vegetarian when I was 18 just to see if I could do it. I soon realized how much healthier I was. I began to watch documentaries and read more about what actually happens to the animals. I wanted to live a compassionate lifestyle. When I was 21, I made the decision to become fully vegan.
bio.history: Battle over Redlands 2012 scaled division, 3rd place Fittest in OK 2013 Rx'd division, 5th place Red dirt classic- team division, 3rd place Battle over Redlands- Rx’d division, 7th place Fittest in OK 2014- team division, 6th place Anarchy in the OK- Rx’d, 3rd place KO in the OK- Rx’d team, 1st place Fittest in OK 2015- Rx’d team, 1st place Fittest Games- Rx’d team- 4th place I will be competing in the Central Regional in Minneapolis, MN.
bio.purpose: I am competitive by nature. I love training and competing to see how hard I can push myself.
bio.diet: it doesn’t change much from what I typically eat day to day.
bio.training: I typically train 3 days on, 1 day off. I will usually do my gym’s workout for the day and then do extra strength and accessory work plus another workout that focuses on my weaknesses.
bio.strongestSkill: handstand push ups and pull ups
bio.proud: My hard work over this last year to get better and making it with a team to go to regionals.

bio.value: hometown New Orleans, current city Los Angeles

I was exposed to veganism through punk and hardcore. I chose a straightedge lifestyle at 14, so I was drawn to straightedge bands and then vegan straightedge bands. I went vegetarian my first year of college, but at the time thought veganism was extreme. 2.5 years later, I realized how ridiculous that thought was as I dove deeper into learning about animal agriculture and animal rights. It was only logical that I took the next step to oppose murder, torture, and rape. I then saw the correlations in other struggles, and ever since, I believe in and fight for Animal, Earth, Human, And Self Liberation. All struggles are one.

value: 2013 OKC California Open Championship - 1st Place Longcycle
2013 IKFF New Orleans Kettlebell Sport Championship - 2nd Place Longcycle
2013 OKC Bay Area Kettlebell Competition - 1st Place Longcycle
2015 OKC California Open Kettlebell Sport Championship - 3rd Place Longcycle
2015 AKA Southwest Regional Kettlebell Championship - 2nd  Place Longcycle
2017 AKA Southwest Regional Kettlebell Championship - 1st Place Snatch
2018 OKC California Open/World Championship - 1st Place Snatch
2018 OKC California Open/World Championship - 1st Place Longcycle

bio.value: I'm actually not a very competitive person. For me, competition is always against myself. That is one of the reasons that I was drawn to the kettlebell sport. In kettlebell sport, you have to dig deep to fight the voices in your head that tell you to drop the bells. It's more mental strength than physical strength. By setting goals for competition, it's the difference between just working out and training. You train with purpose to reach a specific goal. It creates the drive to push yourself further. The process is what drives me more than the competition itself. I always strive to better myself and become more than what I was yesterday.

bio.key: Biggest advantages to being a vegan athlete
bio.value: That's a little hard for me to say. When I competed in Kung Fu as well as kettlebell sport, I was already vegan, so I can't really compare my athleticism to being non-vegan. I will say that it gives me a sense of peace to know that my performances are not fueled by murder.
I don't use many supplements. I like chocolate Green Regimen Elite protein powder, and I take creatine monohydrate.
I pretty much eat the same year round but may increase or decrease caloric intake based on phase of training cycle and goals I'm trying to achieve.
My go to these days are burritos/burrito bowls. I've just been on a big kick where that's what I'm craving a lot.

I train 5-6 days a week. The beginning of each training session is 10-15 minutes of CARS(controlled articular rotations), then depending on the day whatever FRC(functional range conditioning) that I need to focus on to keep my joints mobile, strong, and healthy. Then depending on the day either kettlebell training or cardio training. After the kettlebell training, I will follow it up with whatever accessory strength training exercises I need. Ideally kettlebell and weight training 3 days a week and cardiovascular training 3 days a week.
Pails/Rails, Longcycle, snatch, deadlift, squat, swings, bodyweight movements, bulgarian bag work, mace work, other kettlebell work, martial arts…I like a lot of exercises
The improvements in the clients that I train, both mentally and physically. I love helping people achieve goals that they don’t think that they can accomplish.
